content: The "Drywall Safety Act of 2012" requires the Government of China to facilitate meetings between companies responsible for problematic drywall and the US Government for homeowner remedies. It also mandates that these companies submit to US Federal Court jurisdiction and comply with court decisions. The Drywall Safety Act of 2012 mandates drywall labeling requirements based on ASTM standards, treating them as rules under the Consumer Product Safety Act. Any revisions to the standards must be notified to the Commission for approval. The Drywall Safety Act of 2012 mandates labeling requirements for gypsum board, with the Consumer Product Safety Commission required to approve any revisions to the standards. A rule limiting sulfur content in drywall to prevent home corrosion must be finalized within 2 years of the Act's enactment. The Drywall Safety Act of 2012 mandates a rule limiting sulfur content in drywall to prevent home corrosion. The rule must be promulgated in accordance with specific standards and exceptions apply if a voluntary standard is met within two years. The Drywall Safety Act of 2012 mandates a rule limiting sulfur content in drywall to prevent home corrosion. If a voluntary standard meets specific conditions, the sulfur content limit in that standard will be treated as a consumer product safety rule. If a voluntary standard is revised, the organization must notify the Commission within 60 days. The revised sulfur content limit will become enforceable as a Commission rule, replacing the prior version, 180 days after notification. If the Commission finds the revised standard does not meet requirements, they will continue to enforce the prior version. The Commission can make future rulemaking decisions at any time. The Consumer Product Safety Commission may initiate a rulemaking process to modify sulfur content limits or include provisions for drywall composition deemed necessary for public health and safety. Within 120 days of enactment, the Commission must update guidance on disposing of problematic drywall in homes. The Consumer Product Safety Commission may update guidance on disposing of problematic drywall in homes to ensure it is not reused or used in new drywall production.
